title: Western Economic Sanctions on Russia
summary: Western countries have imposed extensive economic sanctions on Russia following the 2014 Crimea annexation and 2022 Ukraine invasion. These represent the most comprehensive sanctions regime against a major economy in modern history.

russian_perspective.official_narrative: Western sanctions are illegal economic warfare designed to destroy Russian economy and provoke regime change. Russia portrays sanctions as proof of Western hostility and uses them to rally domestic support and justify economic hardships.

response_narrative: Sanctions strengthen Russia by forcing import substitution and self-reliance
Sanctions harm Europe more than Russia (energy dependence)
Russian economy is resilient and adapting
Sanctions reveal Western hypocrisy and double standards
Sanctions accelerate global de-dollarization and multipolarity

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: The sanctions pressure on Russia is a big strategic mistake by the West... The economic blitzkrieg against Russia did not work. The policy of economic oppression failed to produce the desired results.

key_quotes.speaker: Dmitry Medvedev
key_quotes.quote: Hellish sanctions have not worked and will not work. We have everything we need: natural resources, territory, brains.

russian_perspective.evolution: Initial portrayal (2014) as Western attack on Russian development. By 2022, framed as total economic war. Narrative shifted from 'sanctions don't hurt' to 'sanctions make us stronger' as economic pain became undeniable.

western_perspective.official_narrative: Sanctions are necessary response to Russian aggression, designed to impose costs, limit Russia's military capabilities, and signal international disapproval. Goal is to change Russian behavior, not destroy economy.
objectives: Increase economic cost of war for Russia
Limit Russia's ability to finance military operations

verified_claims: Over 11,000 individuals and entities sanctioned by various Western countries
SWIFT restrictions imposed on major Russian banks (2022)
$300+ billion in Russian Central Bank reserves frozen
EU banned Russian oil imports (with phase-out period)
G7 imposed oil price cap mechanism ($60/barrel)
Restrictions on semiconductors and advanced technology exports
Asset freezes on Russian oligarchs totaling tens of billions
economic_impact: Ruble initially crashed but recovered due to capital controls
Russian oil exports redirected from Europe to China/India (at discount)
Some Western companies exited Russia (McDonald's, Starbucks, etc.)
Russian Central Bank restricted to using non-Western currencies
Import of Western goods significantly reduced

data_points.countries_imposing_sanctions: US, EU, UK, Canada, Australia, Japan, South Korea, others

propaganda_techniques_observed: Deflection (focusing on European energy crisis instead of Russian economy)
False equivalence (comparing sanctions to Nazi blockade of Leningrad)
Whataboutism (citing Western sanctions on other countries)

sources.description: IMF: Economic Impact of Sanctions on Russia
